subject: PHYSICS
summary: This lesson will introduce students to different types of energy stores, energy transfer mechanisms, and the concepts of open and closed systems, along with the meaning of work done. The lesson will include interactive elements to engage students and ensure understanding of key concepts.
contentItems: The different types of energy store.
The different ways energy can be transferred.
learningObjectives: Understand and identify different types of energy stores.
Explain how energy can be transferred between systems.
Distinguish between open and closed systems.
Define and apply the concept of work done.
materials: Interactive demonstration equipment (weights and pulley system)

starter.activity: Quick quiz on energy types using flashcards.

mainActivities.activity: Group work: Students create a mind map showing different energy stores and how they transfer energy. Provide clear instructions and support as needed.
Class discussion on open vs closed systems with examples from everyday life. Encourage students to share their own examples.
Interactive demonstration of 'work done' using weights and a pulley system. Allow students to participate in the demonstration.

plenary.activity: Recap key concepts with a Q&A session and summarize the main points of the lesson. Use student responses to reinforce learning.

assessmentMethods: Observation during group work to assess collaboration and understanding
Exit ticket: Students write one thing they learned and one question they still have to promote reflection
Worksheet completion on energy transfers to assess understanding of concepts

homework.task: Complete the worksheet on energy stores and systems, including definitions and examples. Additionally, research and provide a real-world example of energy transfer in action.

teacherNotes: Ensure that all materials are prepared in advance. Check the projector and presentation for any technical issues before the lesson. Be ready to facilitate discussions and provide additional support to students who may struggle with concepts.
